segment.source: Configure MDT for UserExit scripts (Windows 10)
segment.target: Configure MDT for UserExit scripts (Windows 10)

segment.source: In this topic, you will learn how to configure the MDT rules engine to use a UserExit script to generate computer names based on a prefix and the computer MAC Address.
segment.target: In this topic, you will learn how to configure the MDT rules engine to use a UserExit script to generate computer names based on a prefix and the computer MAC Address.

segment.source: Configure MDT for UserExit scripts
segment.target: Configure MDT for UserExit scripts

segment.source: In this topic, you will learn how to configure the MDT rules engine to use a UserExit script to generate computer names based on a prefix and the computer MAC Address.
segment.target: In this topic, you will learn how to configure the MDT rules engine to use a UserExit script to generate computer names based on a prefix and the computer MAC Address.

segment.source: MDT supports calling external VBScripts as part of the Gather process; these scripts are referred to as UserExit scripts.
segment.target: MDT supports calling external VBScripts as part of the Gather process; these scripts are referred to as UserExit scripts.

segment.source: The script also removes the colons in the MAC Address.
segment.target: The script also removes the colons in the MAC Address.

segment.source: Configure the rules to call a UserExit script
segment.target: Configure the rules to call a UserExit script

segment.source: You can call a UserExit by referencing the script in your rules.
segment.target: You can call a UserExit by referencing the script in your rules.

segment.source: Then you can configure a property to be set to the result of a function of the VBScript.
segment.target: Then you can configure a property to be set to the result of a function of the VBScript.

segment.source: In this example, we have a VBScript named Setname.vbs (provided in the book sample files, in the UserExit folder).
segment.target: In this example, we have a VBScript named Setname.vbs (provided in the book sample files, in the UserExit folder).

segment.source: The UserExit=Setname.vbs calls the script and then assigns the computer name to what the SetName function in the script returns.
segment.target: The UserExit=Setname.vbs calls the script and then assigns the computer name to what the SetName function in the script returns.

segment.source: In this sample the %MACADDRESS% variable is passed to the script
segment.target: In this sample the %MACADDRESS% variable is passed to the script

segment.source: The Setname.vbs UserExit script
segment.target: The Setname.vbs UserExit script

segment.source: The Setname.vbs script takes the MAC Address passed from the rules.
segment.target: The Setname.vbs script takes the MAC Address passed from the rules.

segment.source: The script then does some string manipulation to add a prefix (PC) and remove the semicolons from the MAC Address.
segment.target: The script then does some string manipulation to add a prefix (PC) and remove the semicolons from the MAC Address.

segment.source: The first three lines of the script make up a header that all UserExit scripts have.
segment.target: The first three lines of the script make up a header that all UserExit scripts have.

segment.source: The interesting part is the lines between Function and End Function.
segment.target: The interesting part is the lines between Function and End Function.

segment.source: Those lines add a prefix (PC), remove the colons from the MAC Address, and return the value to the rules by setting the SetName value.
segment.target: Those lines add a prefix (PC), remove the colons from the MAC Address, and return the value to the rules by setting the SetName value.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The purpose of this sample is not to recommend that you use the MAC Address as a base for computer naming, but to show you how to take a variable from MDT, pass it to an external script, make some changes to it, and then return the new value to the deployment process.
segment.target: The purpose of this sample is not to recommend that you use the MAC Address as a base for computer naming, but to show you how to take a variable from MDT, pass it to an external script, make some changes to it, and then return the new value to the deployment process.
